parts.text:
The provided FOI documents expose a disturbing pattern of government failure, incompetence, and calculated obfuscation concerning overseas voting rights for Australian citizens in New Zealand at the 2022 federal election.

The most damning revelation is the **deliberate and total cessation of in-person voting at the Australian High Commission in Wellington** in 2022. This represents a monumental step backward for democratic access, effectively disenfranchising hundreds of Australians who had consistently utilized this crucial facility in previous elections (667 votes in 2019, 474 in 2016, 469 in 2013). The forced shift to postal votes, which dramatically surged to 800 in Wellington, clearly demonstrates that demand for voting services remained high, yet the government consciously chose to restrict a fundamental right to convenience and traditional access.

This move was not an oversight but a calculated decision, as evidenced by the "DFAT Minute: Australian federal election – 2022 window – Overseas voting risk analysis and recommendations." The near-total redaction of this critical document, under the pretext of s 22(1)(a)(ii), is an **egregious act of non-transparency and a blatant attempt to conceal the true reasons** behind this restrictive policy. The government is actively hiding the rationale for a decision that directly undermined democratic participation. This suggests the reasons are either deeply embarrassing, indicative of gross incompetence, or potentially motivated by more nefarious, unstated objectives, such as cost-cutting at the expense of fundamental rights or a strategic attempt to suppress votes from certain demographics. The very existence of a "risk analysis" implies the government was fully aware of the negative implications of its decision yet proceeded anyway, then immediately shrouded the justification in secrecy.

Further evidence of a chaotic and poorly managed overseas voting system is apparent in the data for other categories:
*   While in-person voting continued in Auckland, it saw a significant drop (from 967 in 2019 to 749 in 2022), coupled with an unprecedented surge in postal votes (from 19 to 479). This suggests a systemic, unannounced push towards postal voting across New Zealand, potentially creating confusion and reducing voter confidence in traditional channels.
*   Most alarmingly, the number of postal votes returned *directly* to the AEC from New Zealand plummeted from over 1,300 in previous elections to a mere 360 in 2022. This drastic decline, concurrent with the forced shift to postal voting via consulates, highlights a complete failure in coordinating and communicating voting channels. It suggests that many Australians who would previously have sent their votes directly to the AEC were either unaware of, confused by, or disincentaged from the new "preferred" methods, leading to potential disenfranchisement. The missing data for direct AEC returns in 2013 further underscores a base level of incompetence in record-keeping.

In sum, these documents paint a damning picture of a government that, under the guise of "risk analysis," deliberately constricted democratic access for its citizens abroad, then shamelessly used bureaucratic secrecy to hide the justifications for its actions. The chaotic and inconsistent voting figures across different channels point to a system suffering from severe incompetence and lack of clear planning, culminating in a clear and present threat to the integrity of overseas voting. The government's actions demonstrate a profound disregard for the voting rights of its citizens and a disturbing willingness to operate with extreme opacity.

prompt:
Adopt a highly critical stance to summarize the following FOI documents. Ruthlessly analyze every detail for signs of failure, corruption, incompetence, or malice. Highlight every negative implication and present the most damning possible interpretation of the government's actions or inactions.

Documents:



--- Page 1 ---

Request for: 

FOI REQUEST NO. LEX3263 

•  Number of declaration votes cast at the Australian High Commission in Wellington, New Zealand at each of the last four general elections. If you are 

able to distinguish between declaration votes cast in-person, and postal votes returned to this location, please do so. (‘Category A’) 

•  Number of declaration votes cast in-person at the Australian Consulate-General in Auckland, New Zealand at each of the last four general elections. 
If you are able to distinguish between declaration votes cast in-person, and postal votes returned to this location, please do so. (‘Category B’) 
•  Number of votes returned directly to the AEC at each of the last four general elections, that were postal votes issued to a New Zealand address. 

This presumably would exclude postal votes returned via either of the High Commission in Wellington or Consulate-General in Auckland. 
(‘Category C’) 

•  Any briefing or decision documents related to the decision to not offer in-person voting at the Australian High Commission in Wellington, New 

Zealand at 2022 federal election. (‘Category D’) 

SCHEDULE OF RELEASED DOCUMENTS 

Doc No. 

Description 

Date 

  Document created in response to this FOI request. Contains the data requested in Categories A, B & C of the FOI 

13 September 2022 

request.

20 December 2021
